column2: persistence.js is an asynchronous Javascript database mapper library. You can use it in the browser, as well on the server (and you can share data models between them).

Fixes this: https://github.com/zefhemel/persistencejs/issues/109
Fix __defineSetter__ & __defineGetter__ issued by IE9

Migrating downwards should set version one lower

Currently if one migrates downwards, the version is set to the last down migration ran.

Instead, it should be the new current version.

Fix #97 Migrating downwards goes too far

When migrating downwards, don't migrate down the version we're trying to get to.

This should fix #97 .
Simples Possible PHP Sync Service
Adding minimal PHP Sync Service

Fixed removing local (_new) objects

If an object was created, added and removed without flushing in between, it
was still persisted. Fixed by directly removing _new objects from the
trackedObjects array.

Fixed arrayRemove() helper function

The function was broken in a way that when it actually removed an item from
the array, it would run over the end of the array, throwing an exception
trying to work with a null element. Fixed by returning directly after
deleting an element. This is OK since the method is only used for arrays
without duplicate elements.

Also added a test case that uses arrayRemove() (indirectly).

Support case-insensitive QueryCollection ordering

By default, ordering is case sensitive. Using a new parameter of
QueryCollection.order(), it can be made case insensitive. The behavior
of using insensitive ordering with anything else than TEXT fields is
undefined.
Added name of Entity to log message on line 462.
insert new objects with only a id column

Revert "Trigger events in persistence.add()"

While triggering correct events for persistence.add(), this change introduced
duplicate events to be triggered for QueryCollection.prototype.add().

This reverts commit 1af51e878b707618b45580121cb3093d0f05a59e.

Trigger events in persistence.add()

When an object is added using persistence.add(), 'add' and 'change' events
are triggered, similar to persistence.remove().
Check for value in milliseconds
Appending obj.id sends the id from the _SyncRemovedObject table; appending obj.objectId actually sends the record's real id, which is more useful for syncing.

Fix for issue #56

Changed the connection code to accommodate changes in node-mysql >= 0.9.2. Tested (manually) and works as intended.

See: https://github.com/zefhemel/persistencejs/issues/56

Signed-off-by: Josh Smith <joshdotsmith@gmail.com>

* Fixed entity's `fetch` method. Will actually work now (apparently nobody

* Added better `toJSON()` method to entity objects for better
  JSON.stringify serialization.

Added `reverse()` to query collections. This is useful if you want to
reverse a collection after the resultset has been calculated. For
instance to get the last 10 entries, in ascending order:

SomeEntity.all().order("date",
false).limit(10).reverse().list(function(results) {
  ...
});

The `order` there orders the results in descending order, but the
`reverse()` reverses that order again in the result set. Was useful for
me in some places.

Also replaced the node.js MySQL driver with a different one (see source
file).
